title: Adding a dash of relish to the so-called dismal science: A toothsome twist to economics
text:
The revelation, made by his brother, that Kolkata-born Abhijit Banerjee, co-recipient of this year’s Nobel Prize for Economics, is a great chef and can provide a feast for family and friends at the drop of a toque should occasion little or no surprise either to practitioners of the dismal science, or to those dedicated to the pursuit of gastronomy. The fundamentals underlying the discipline of Keynes and Freidman might seem as simple as ABC, going by Mr Micawber’s benefic calculus of financial prudence and contentment: “Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen pounds, nineteen shilling, and six pence, result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pounds ought and six, result misery.”

However, like the devil, divergences lie in the details of distinction between supply-side and demand side, monetary policy and fiscal policy, and all the other policies which go to make or break the wealth of nations. In that economists are known to not only bake but also take the cake when it comes to dishing out facts, figures, and statistics to suit all budgets and Budgets, their profession can be likened to that of confectioners, though the fare they offer may be far from sweet. Perhaps it is no linguistic coincidence that the colloquial term for money, central theme all of economic theory and practice, is `bread’ or that those who control the state’s purse strings deal with pie charts and engage in debate as to how best to bring home the bacon. In keeping with this foodie tradition it’s little wonder that Abhijit is an exemplar of RCT – Remarkable Culinary Talent.
